Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Multi-Arterial vs. Single-Arterial Grafting in OPCABG for Patients with Reduced Left Ventricular Function

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included patients with a left ventricular ejection fraction of less than 50% undergoing OPCABG. A total of 86 patients were randomised

Participants.evidence: patients with a left ventricular ejection fraction of less than 50% undergoing OPCABG. Conducted at the First Affiliated Hospital of Zhengzhou University

Intervention.evidence: 22 to the multi-arterial group and 64 to the single-arterial group

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the perioperative and mid-term outcomes of multi-arterial versus single-arterial grafting in off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting (OPCABG) for patients with reduced left ventricular function.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) over a follow-up period of 29.28±14.84 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients, clinicians, or outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 86 patients were randomised: 22 to the multi-arterial group and 64 to the single-arterial group, from January 2018 to December 2021.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Logistic regression analysis identified female gender (OR: 0.191, 95% CI: 0.049-0.075) and creatinine (OR: 1.016, 95% CI: 1.000-1.033) as predictors of MACE.

Harms.evidence: The multi-arterial group had a higher incidence of postoperative hypotension (34.78% vs. 11.54%, P=0.009).
